results.title: The Power game
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The third episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the division of power in the Parliament and the Executive in Australia, with particular attention to Federal and State Powers and their differences. The program offers definitions of and discussions about Parliament and the Executive as well as Federal, State and Local governments by the range of contributors to the program, along with their responsive commentary about questions such as, is there a ‘State and Federal Fiscal Imbalance? What is the power of external affairs? These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Brian Galligan, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Justice Michael Kirby, Kim Rubenstein, Kristen Walker, Sir Ninian Stephen and Professor Cheryl Saunders.

results.title: An Australian Republic?
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The second episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the notion of an Australian Republic and the potential changes in the Constitution this would require and how they would be determined. At the opening of the program questions are put forward such as, what would the role, functions and powers of the Head of State be? Would the Head of State be elected or selected within government? What impact would an Australian Republic have on the States? This is followed by responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Noel Pearson, Professor Leslie Zines and His Excellency the Honourable Richard McGarvie.

results.title: The Australian Constitution
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
This first episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series introduces the study of the Australian Constitution through discussion of its historical foundations and development. At the opening of the program questions are put forward such as what does the Australian Constitution do? Where does the Australian Constitution come from? Does it reflect reality? Where do Indigenous people fare in the Australian Constitution? This is followed by a responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Tony Blackshield, Sir Zelman Cowan QC, Chief Justice of NSW Murray Gleeson, Professor Stuart Macintyre, Senate Clerk Harry Evans, Kristen Walker, Anne Mullins and Hugh Mackay.

results.title: Mr Strehlow's films
results.creator_credit: Hart Cohen, Adrian Herring, Journocam Prod and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: TGH Strehlow was an anthropologist who spent most of his working life documenting on 16mm film the lives of the Aboriginal communities of Central Australia. His anthropological work resulted in the establishment of the Strehlow Institute near Alice Springs which exhibits the full extent of his documentary legacy. In recent years, Strehlow’s work has been criticised as being patronising in his relationship to indigenous communities. This insightful and compelling documentary presents both a biography of Strehlow as well as a critique of some of the racial assumptions that underlie European anthropological exploration of Aboriginal culture. Strehlow’s recording of sacred rituals involving Aboriginal men and youth has resulted in complex questions regarding the use, distribution and legitimacy of such material. In addressing such questions, ‘Mr. Strehlow’s films’ illuminates the changing relationship between European and Aboriginal Australians. The images from the documentary also present astounding records of desert life in Australia in the early part of the twentieth century. A comprehensive 10 page study guide to the film can be downloaded at: http://www.enhancetv.com.au/study_it/MrStrehlowsFilms.pdf

results.title: Blackout: poison [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley and ABC-TV (Australia). Indigenous Program Unit
results.brief_description: Using real photos, images, staged settings and live performances, this episode, the first in the “Blackout” series, looks at the issues of assimilation, forced adoption and sexual abuse - particularly in respect of how it can lead to addictive personalities. It is also about the universal struggle of wanting to be loved, needed and accepted. The story centres around four people sharing a city squat, 24 hours in the lives of Raylene (Lydia Miller), Wayne (Russell Page), Laniece (Rhoda Roberts) and Sharon (Lillian Crombie) as they are involved in a drunken and stoned evening out, each plagued by their past and struggling to move forward with their future. Cast also includes Willurai Kirkbright Burney. Performances arranged by Stephen Page.

results.title: Makin pitchas
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: Makin Pitchas is a compilation of four short films made by young Kooris who are a part of the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative (BADAC). The project was an initiative funded by VicHealth to encourage young Kooris to explore and articulate their experiences of mental health issues, most particularly family issues, grief, conflict, racism and bullying. The final product is intended to promote discussion of mental health issues among young people in Indigenous communities as well as acting as a tool for cross cultural education in mainstream organisations. “Believe in Yourself” (dir. Tim Stares) is the story of Dave, a koori youth who feels alienated and discouraged by his parents who would prefer he drop out of school and lay bricks for his father rather than follow his dream to be a filmmaker. “A World of Colour” (dir. Myles Walsh) focuses on a mediation session, after a basketball game turns into a racial slagging match. “Goodnight Irene” (dir. Tim Stares) tells the story of Ruth, a young girl who has to do a history project about family’s pastimes. Unfortunately she cannot report anything to her teacher because the memories her mother has of her past are too painful to discuss. In “Verandah Dreaming” (dir. Myles Walsh) Verna loses her husband in the war and her son to drugs. Hope seems further lost when her grandson is sent to prison for stealing a car. However, with the help of the Aboriginal Legal Service, Sammy joins an Aboriginal Dance group and finds direction to his life.

results.title: Mabo: the native title revolution
results.creator_credit: Rob Wellington, Trevor Graham, Cristina Pozzan, Buona Notte Productions, Film Australia and Tantamount Productions
results.brief_description:
An extensive multimedia resource that explores a pivotal moment in Australian history—the landmark Mabo legal case in which the High Court acknowledged the claim of Aboriginal Australians to native title. Combining 2 CD ROM’s with a website and online database, the project brings together a documentary video with hundreds of specially created audio-visual sequences and a wealth of text and images covering issues from colonisation and indigenous culture to land rights and native title. Suitable for senior secondary, undergraduate and research at adult levels. A website has been created as part of this project containing updates, additional material, technical information and links to other related sites. Available online at www.MaboNativeTitle.com Study notes and related material can be printed from the Film Australia website at http://www.filmast.com.au

SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: PC: Multimedia capable machines/Operating System: All Windows 32 bit operating systems/Memory: 16 mb free RAM - 20 mb physical RAM a minimum/CD-ROM Drive: 4 speed/Display: 640 x 480 pixels in 16 bit (thousands of colours). Macintosh Processor: PowerMac or better/Operating System: 7.5 or above/Memory: 24 mb/CD-ROM Drive: 4 speed/Display: 640 x 480 pixels in 16 bit colour.

results.title: Milliya rumarra = Brand new day
results.creator_credit: Bryan McLellan, David Noakes, I F Productions and W A Filmworkers
results.brief_description: Aboriginal education is a part of life in aboriginal communities and survival of aboriginal culture and language is through the young. This documentary records the celebration of the first Aboriginal Arts in Perth 83 festival which attracted participants from all over Australia, including Maureen Watson, Jack Davis and Vic Hunter. Traditional dance, song and story-telling were a feature and interaction with the audience was encouraged - a way of sharing the Aboriginal culture with non-Aboriginal Australians. The film also documents Aboriginal community members from the Mowanjum Community in Derby, WA and the Warmun Community in Turkey Creek, WA, visiting schools in Perth, teaching the school-children about Aboriginal culture and traditions in an effort to improve race relations and bridge the gap of understanding between all Australians.

results.title: New Norcia voices
results.creator_credit: A. Bruce Hodsdon and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A companian piece to ‘New Norcia’ that contributes valuable background information this documentary combines interviews with a monk at the New Norcia monastery, historians, and aboriginal men and women who were brought-up at the mission. Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.

Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.

Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.

results.title: New Norcia. New Norcia voices
results.creator_credit: A. Bruce Hodsdon and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A compilation of two companion films. ‘New Norcia’ (23 mins. 1990) is a representation through images and journal extracts of the history of contact between European and Aboriginal cultures, circa 1850-1900 at the Benedictine Mission at New Norcia in Western Australia. ‘New Norcia Voices’ (19 mins. 1992) combines interviews with a monk at the monastery, historians, and men and women who were brought-up at the mission. Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.’New Norcia’ narrated by Ian Taylor.

Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.’New Norcia’ narrated by Ian Taylor.
